@usr2564301 IDA has a debugger and OP explicitly states multiple times he's debugging using IDA...

IDA has even several debugger backends and even allows for remote debugging. Frankly I prefer it whenever I don't have the source to something available. Otherwise I prefer WinDbg and x64dbg and then with some space the VS debugger follows ...

answers_data.content: IDA debugger for win32 is pretty unstable, especially when you load a big file into ida (bigger than 20 mb), and then try to debug it. You can try attaching to a running process from IDA, instead of loading exe for disassembly first. Also, I would suggest trying the other debugging backends like Windbg (Debugger - Select debugger menu). You'll need debugging tools for Windows. And if there's no specific need to debug from IDA, then use Windbg directly.

comments.text: That's a pretty generic statement. For starters I've never had the instability issues you describe and then given you're making such a claim you might want to point out the version of IDA you're running as well as the backend you are using.
If you want to experience some problems try loading chrome_child.dll and then start debugging. It's going to die trying to relocate the image. IDA x64 version survives this, x86 - dies.
